April 1919.SECRET.1':WAR CABINET 559.Minutes of a Meeting of the War Cabinet, held at 10, Downing Street, SAW., onWednesday, April 23, 1919, at 12 noon.Present:The Right Hon. A. Bonar Law, M.P. (in the Chair).The Right Hon. the Earl Curzon of kedleston, KG, G.C.S.I., G.C.I.E.The Right Hon. A. Chamberlain, M.P.The following were also present:The Right Hon.. the Viscount Milner, i Major-General Sir C. H. Harington,G.C.B., G.C.M.G., Secretary of State lorthe Colonies.Sir G. V. Fiddes, G.C.M.G., K.C.B.,Permanent Under-Secretary of State forthe Colonies (for Minutes 1-3).K.C.B., D.S.O, Deputy Chief of theImperial General Staff (for Minutes 1-5).Mr. Thomas Jones, Acting Secretary.Lieutenant-colonel] L. Stoke, C.B., Assistant Secretary.Brigadier-General S. II. Wilson, C.B., C.M.G., Secretary, Oversea Defence and home Ports Committees.Liquor Eestrictionand Control.1. The Chancellor of the Exchequer informed the WarCabinet of certain changes which he proposed to introduce in theBudget as the result of a meeting of the Liquor RestrictionsCommittee, held on the previous day, and of conferences whichhad taken place between himself, Mr. Bouar Law, and Lord Milner.Post-war ImperialGarrisons inSouth Africa.2. The War Cabinet had under consideration a Memorandumby the Oversea Defence Committee on Post-war Imperial garrisons in South Africa (Paper 116-G.)The War Cabinet approved, subject to the matter being dis-cussed by the Secretary of State for the Colonies withGeneral Botha, of the War Office acting on the assump-tions . (a.) That a garrison of Imperial troops will not berequired in the future in the interior of SouthAfrica ;(b.) That, with the exception of the Cape Peninsuladefences, the Union Government will provide andman the defences of any defended ports whichit may be decided to maintain in South Africa,[826]-559 Restrictions onuse of BritishOversea Ports.3. With reference to War Cabinet 51G, Minute 7, the WarCabinet had under consideration a Memorandum by the OverseaDefence Committee on Restrictions on Use of British Oversea Ports(Paper 117-G).The Secretary of State for the Colonies said that his predecessors-cessor at the Colonial Office had strongly held the view that allColonies and Protectorates should be invited to legislate, withoutdelay, prohibiting Germans from entering, residing, or tradinglocally in their territory for a period of five years from the end ofthe Avar, and that a despatch to the Colonies on these lines had beenprepared in the Colonial Office. He (Lord Milner) thought thatsuch action was premature until the conclusion of the Peace Con-ference, and he had stopped the issue of the despatch. He wouldlike the matter to remain in abeyance for the present, or else have itdiscussed again by the War Cabinet.Mr. Bonar Law agreed that it would be better not to take any action until the conclusion of peace.The War Cabinet took note of the views held by the Admiralty,the War Office, the Air Ministry, the Board of Trade, and theMinistry of Shipping, as regards it being contrary to British interests to depart from the pre-war policy of placing as few restrictions aspossible on the use of British ports abroad by foreign vessels, and of inducing foreign navies and auxiliary fleets to become dependent onthese ports.The War Cabinet approved the proposal that no action shouldbe taken by the Secretary of State for the Colonies on war Cabinet decision 516, minute 7, pending the con-clusion of peace.Military, Naval,and Air ForcePensions.4. The War Cabinet had under consideration a Memorandumby the Chancellor of the Exchequer on Military, Naval, and AirForce Pensions (Paper G.T.-7116).The Chancellor of the Exchequer said that the proposal wasthat a Committee, composed of the Financial Secretary of theTreasury as Chairman, and representatives of the War Office, theAdmiralty, the Air Force, and the Pensions Ministry, should examine and report upon the schemes proposed by the different departments.Mr. Bonar Law suggested that it might be better if theMinister of Pensions were to act as Chairman to the Committee.The War Cabinet decided that A Committee should be appointed to consider the matter,composed as follows : The Minister of Pensions (Chairman),Representatives of The Treasury.The War Office,The Admiralty,The Air Ministry,Policy ofRepatriatingRussian Prisonersof War fromGermany.5. The War Cabinet had under consideration a Note by theSecretary of State for War, on the question of repatriating russian prisoners of war from Germany, via the Western frontiers of Russia.(Paper G.T.-7I34).Mr. Bonar Law said that, while agreeing with the views expressed in the War Office Note, he was not quite clear as to what action could be taken by the War Cabinet, beyond sending the WarOffice Note to the Prime Minister and saying that the War cabinet agreed with the views expressed1. 3 . WC 559The Acting Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs was strongly of opinion that it was undesirable to repatriate the prisoners. Theprinciple had, however, been accepted at Paris about a fortnightpreviously, at a meeting which had been held at Mr. Lloyd George'house.The Deputy Chief of the Imperial General Staff said thatattempts were being made to collect anti-Bolshevik prisoners. Sofar as he knew, nothing had as yet been done as regards repatriatingthe prisoners, and the War Office sincerely hoped that it would be stopped.The War Cabinet decided that *A copy of the War Office Note should be sent to the primeMinister, with a message stating that the War Cabinetconcurred in the views expressed therein, and instructed the Acting Secretary to take the necessary action.Peace Celebrations. 6. With reference to War Cabinet 534, Minute 12, Lord Curzonraised the question of the date and the character of the celebrationsconsidered desirable.The general view of the War Cabinet was in favour of an earlycelebration, bv means of (a.) A military demonstration on a Saturday ;(6.) Thanksgiving services on the Sunday following.7. The Chancellor of the Exchequer raised the question of theEmployment in Public Departments of Persons of Alien Origin.(Paper G.T.-7115).The War Cabinet decided that The question should be considered by the Committee of HomeAffairs.Employment inPublicDepartments ofPersons of AlienOrigin.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W. 1,April 23, 1919.o
